analysis.title: Man Wedding
analysis.author: Amos Posner
analysis.logline: When a commitment-phobic lawyer agrees to plan his own wedding to avoid traditional ceremonies, his elaborate schemes spiral into the exact spectacle he was trying to escape.
analysis.tone: Light comedic with moments of genuine emotion

hook_clarity.note: Clear role reversal - man plans wedding

freshness.note: Gender role reversal adds some novelty

concept.justification: The gender role reversal of having the male plan the wedding offers a fresh angle on wedding comedies, though the core premise remains familiar territory.
page_citations: Page 17: Aggie proposes Tom plan the wedding himself
concept.weakness_identified: Concept relies heavily on execution and supporting characters to elevate familiar wedding comedy tropes

scene_necessity.note: Most scenes serve purpose but some feel padded

structure.justification: Solid three-act structure with clear escalation. Wedding planning complications build effectively to the overblown Beervana wedding, with satisfying intimate resolution in Vegas.
page_citations: Page 28: Inciting incident - Tom agrees to plan
structure.weakness_identified: Some scenes in Act 2 feel like comedic padding rather than essential story progression

goal_clarity.note: Wants to avoid traditional wedding spectacle

active_agency.note: Makes choices but often reacts to escalation

protagonist.justification: Tom's goal of avoiding wedding spectacle is clear, but he becomes increasingly passive as the planning spirals. His transformation feels rushed in the final act.
protagonist.weakness_identified: Tom becomes too passive in Act 2, letting others drive the action rather than making active choices that create consequences

character_distinction.note: Characters have clear voices and quirks

supporting_cast.justification: Strong ensemble with distinct personalities. Ben provides heart, Aggie grounds the story, and the poker buddies create escalating complications. Each character serves clear story functions.
page_citations: Page 35: Poker buddies volunteer for wedding tasks
supporting_cast.weakness_identified: Some characters like Uncle Al and parents feel more like types than fully realized people

quotability.note: Some amusing lines but nothing iconic

dialogue.justification: Dialogue is serviceable with distinct character voices. Humor tends toward situational rather than verbal wit. Some emotional moments feel authentic.
page_citations: Page 16: 'I don't not want to marry you' - captures Tom's resistance
Page 106: 'It's always both' - reveals character truth
dialogue.weakness_identified: Dialogue often states subtext directly rather than letting it emerge naturally through conflict and behavior

genre_execution.justification: Solid romantic comedy execution with all required beats present. The wedding disaster and intimate resolution provide satisfying genre payoffs. The male perspective adds freshness to familiar territory.
page_citations: Page 87: Breakup scene with real emotional stakes
genre_execution.weakness_identified: While competent, doesn't push genre boundaries enough to feel truly innovative

originality.justification: The male wedding planner angle provides some novelty, but execution follows familiar romantic comedy patterns without significant innovation in voice or approach.
originality.weakness_identified: Script doesn't establish a sufficiently distinctive voice or approach to elevate it above competent but familiar territory

cultural_resonance.rationale: Universal themes of family pressure, wedding expectations, and authentic relationships translate exceptionally well to Latin American family-centered culture

regional_casting_potential.rationale: Lead roles perfect for actors like Omar Chaparro or Mauricio Ochmann, with Aggie suitable for Stephanie Cayo or Ana de la Reguera

theatrical_appeal.rationale: Light romantic comedy with broad appeal, though not necessarily event cinema

marketing_viability.rationale: Clear hook - 'What if the GUY planned the wedding?' - works well for posters and trailers

coproduction_potential.rationale: Perfect Mexico/US co-production - could be adapted to Mexican wedding traditions while maintaining universal appeal

major_weaknesses: Protagonist becomes too passive in Act 2
Relies heavily on supporting characters to drive comedy
Limited originality beyond gender role premise
Some scenes feel like padding rather than essential story progression

target_audience.note: Rom-com audience clear but competitive market

high_concept.note: Takes some explanation beyond simple hook

cast_attachability.note: Good ensemble roles, lead somewhat limited

budget_return_ratio.note: Low budget with solid return potential

comparable_success.note: Wedding comedies have mixed track record

structure_analysis.act_breaks: Act 1 ends page 28 with wedding planning agreement, Act 2 escalates through page 87 breakup, Act 3 resolves with Vegas wedding
structure_analysis.pacing: Steady escalation with good comedic beats, though some padding in middle section

characters.protagonist: Tom Neyer - commitment-phobic lawyer who wants to avoid wedding spectacle but gets overwhelmed by planning process. Goal clear but becomes passive.
characters.antagonist: No clear antagonist - conflict comes from Tom's own fears and escalating circumstances

standout_scenes.scene: Poker game where guys volunteer to help
standout_scenes.why: Establishes ensemble dynamic and escalates stakes naturally
Genuine emotional confrontation with real stakes

standout_scenes.scene: Tom and Aggie reunion in Vegas dive bar
standout_scenes.why: Authentic character moments with real vulnerability

comparable_films.title: The Hangover
comparable_films.similarity: Male ensemble comedy with escalating chaos

target_audience.gender_skew: neutral with slight male skew due to perspective
target_audience.latam_audience_notes: Family-centered culture makes wedding themes highly relatable; male perspective could attract broader audience than typical rom-coms

budget_tier.justification: Contemporary settings, no major VFX, manageable cast size

strengths: Strong cultural fit for Latin American market
Clear commercial hook with gender role reversal
Manageable budget with good return potential
weaknesses: Protagonist becomes too passive in Act 2
Some scenes feel padded rather than essential
Relies heavily on supporting characters for comedy
development_notes: Strengthen Tom's active agency throughout Act 2
Elevate dialogue with more subtext and distinctive voice
Trim unnecessary scenes to improve pacing
assessment.recommendation_rationale: Weighted score of 5.90 with no critical failures and strong Latin American market fit qualifies for CONSIDER. CVS of 14 supports commercial viability despite competitive genre.

film_now_assessment.lightning_test: Opening wedding scene establishes premise but lacks visceral hook
film_now_assessment.career_risk_test: Solid but not exceptional - wouldn't stake career on this alone
film_now_assessment.legacy_potential: Unlikely to be remembered in 20 years - competent but not groundbreaking

analysis.verdict_statement: CONSIDER for development. Solid romantic comedy with strong Latin American market potential elevated by gender role reversal premise, but needs work on protagonist agency and dialogue elevation to reach full commercial potential.
analysis.executive_summary: Wedding comedy with male planner angle offers fresh perspective on familiar genre. Strong LatAm cultural fit and manageable budget, but needs development on protagonist agency and originality.
